February 19, 1984: Fiction
PET SEMATARY, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The new family in town
discovers the horrors that lie in a neighboring cemetery.
WHO KILLED THE ROBINS FAMILY?, created by Bill Adler and written by
Thomas Chastain. (Morrow, $9.95.) The publisher offers a $10,000 prize to the
reader who submits the best answer.
POLAND, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Seven centuries of
history in fictional form.
SMART WOMEN, by Judy Blume. (Putnam, $15.95.) Three divorcees, their love
affairs and their kids in trendy Boulder, Colo.
ALMOST PARADISE , by Susan Isaacs. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) Three
generations of show-biz people play out their destinies on two continents.
BERLIN GAME, by Len Deighton. (Knopf, $15.95.) Espionage on both sides of the
Iron Curtain.
THE STORY OF HENRI TOD, by William F. Buckley Jr. (Doubleday, $14.95.)
Superspy Blackford Oakes carries out a mission in Berlin at the time The Wall
goes up.
THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace
Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian
monastery.
NIGHT SKY, by Clare Francis. (Morrow, $16.95.) The intertwined lives of three
people through the past 50 years.
THE JOURNEYER, by Gary Jennings. (Atheneum, $17.95.) Marco Polo's journey
to the Orient in the 13th century.
CHANGES, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.95.) The crises that arise when a
television anchorwoman and a glamorous physician fall in love.
THE WICKED DAY, by Mary Stewart. (Morrow, $16.95.) King Arthur, fulfilling a
prophecy made by Merlin, falls into an incestuous relationship.
RAINSONG, by Phyllis A. Whitney. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The enigmas that
perplex the widow of a rock-music idol.
MORETA: DRAGONLADY OF PERN, by Anne McCaffrey. (Del Rey/Ballantine,
$14.95.) A battle against ecological disaster on a faraway planet.
NERVE ENDINGS, by William Martin. (Crown, $14.95.) The wife of a TV producer
races and chases to save him from the consequences of a near-fatal accident.
February 19, 1984
Non-Fiction
IN SEARCH OF EXCELLENCE, by Thomas J. Peters and Robert H. Waterman Jr.
(Harper & Row, $19.95.) Lessons to be learned from well-run American
corporations.
MOTHERHOOD: The Second Oldest Profession, by Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-
Hill, $12.95.) A humorous look at the biggest on-the-job training program ever.
TOUGH TIMES NEVER LAST, BUT TOUGH PEOPLE DO! by Robert H. Schuller.
(Thomas Nelson, $12.95.) Inspiration from a California preacher.
ON WINGS OF EAGLES, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $17.95.) The rescue of two
Americans from an Iranian prison.
THE BEST OF JAMES HERRIOT. (St. Martin's Press, $19.95.) Selections from
the writings of the Yorkshire veterinarian.
THE DISCOVERERS, by Daniel J. Boorstin. (Random, $25.) Man's search to
know himself and the world over the centuries.
APPROACHING HOOFBEATS: HORSEMEN OF THE APOCALYPSE, by Billy
Graham. (Word Books, $11.95.) The evangelist's interpretation of the Book of
Revelation.
MAYOR, by Edward I. Koch with William Rauch. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) New
York's Mayor's opinions about his job, his city and the world.
CORONER, by Thomas T. Noguchi with Joseph DiMona. (Simon & Schuster,
$16.95.) The controversial Los Angeles County medical examiner discusses the
deaths of Marilyn Monroe, John Belushi and other celebrities.
PEOPLE OF THE LIE, by M. Scott Peck. (Simon & Schuster, $14.95.) A
psychiatrist's prescription for ''healing human evil.''
THE PETER PAN SYNDROME, by Dan Kiley. (Dodd, Mead, $15.95.) A
psychologist's analysis of the plight of men who have never grown up.
A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $12.45.) Light verse
and drawings by the author.
MEGATRENDS, by John Naisbitt. (Warner, $17.50.) Predictions about America in
the next decade based on an analysis of conditions today.
WHILE REAGAN SLEPT, by Art Buchwald. (Putnam, $14.95.) Seven score wry
observations on the Washington scene by the syndicated columnist.
TOUGH-MINDED FAITH FOR TENDERHEARTED PEOPLE, by Robert H.
Schuller. (Thomas Nelson, $14.95.) More inspiration from a California preacher.
